blocks.data: Measurements on Magento Cloud Infrastructure - B2C
<w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/>Helix Team<w:br/>Cloud, Performance & Measurements

This white paper contains results of performance measurements of Magento Commerce 2.2.4 running on Magento Cloud Pro infrastructure for cases of Small, Medium, Large and Extra-large profiles. Measurements track response rates captured for high-loaded eCommerce sites on Magento Cloud Pro production environments 12 to 120.<w:br/><w:br/>All performance measurements are based on simulated day-to-day store activities for customers and business users. The values do not reflect maximum throughout or reflect unique business models, like private sales or flash sales.<w:br/><w:br/>This information aids eCommerce managers and technical staff to better understand the performance characteristics of the application and select an appropriate plan for Magento Commerce store using Magento Cloud environments and services.<w:br/><w:br/>When considering Magento Cloud for your Magento Commerce storefronts, review Instance Profile Configuration to determine which profile meets the size of your storefront. All performance results in this white paper are titled by profile and environment size.

Magento Commerce (Cloud) environments for 12 with Small and Medium profiles and 24 with Medium profile, can serve described load without any specific customizations and demonstrate above response time results for day-to-day store activities and sales.<li>Magento Commerce (Cloud) environments for 12, 24, 48 with Large profile and 48 and 120 with Extra Large profile require customizations in Magento code/infrastructure.<li>API performance scenarios demonstrate acceptable results, with the exception of Get/Create product cases for profiles larger than Small.<li>Client-side performance tests demonstrated good results.<li>Full indexation for Large and Extra-large profile takes a significant amount of time.<li>Emulating real instances, 60% cache hit rate was used during the measurements that implies more time of response caused by request to application and subsequent processes.

The scenarios use the following data profiles. Each data profile includes a number of sites, products, and categories matching stores typically considered small, medium, large, and extra-large B2C installations.<w:br/><w:br/>All profiles are available through the Magento 2 GitHub repository, Profiles.<w:br/>

rows.text: * Websites/stores/stores view: 1 (total)<w:br/>* Individual simple products: 800<w:br/>* Configurable products: 40(with 15 simple products for each configurable product, ~ 600 simple products)<w:br/>* Categories: 30<w:br/>* Customers: 200

* Websites/stores/stores view: 3 (total)<w:br/>Individual simple products: 24,000<w:br/>* Configurable products: 640(with 11 simple products for each configurable product, ~ 7,000 simple products)<w:br/>* Categories: 300<w:br/>* Customers: 2,000

* Websites/stores/stores view: 5 (total)<w:br/>* Individual simple products: 300,000<w:br/>* Configurable products: 8,000(with 11 simple products for each configurable product, ~ 88,000 simple products)<w:br/>* Categories: 3,000<w:br/>* Customers: 5,000

* Websites/stores/stores view: 5 (total)<w:br/>* Individual simples: 600,000<w:br/>* Configurable products: 16,000(with 11 simple products for each configurable product, ~ 176,000 simple products)<w:br/>* Categories: 6,000<w:br/>* Customers: 10,000

blocks.data: Every experiment uses the profiles listed in Instance Profile Configuration. These experiments use the following parameters.

Cache hit/miss rate: 0% cache hit, means that with avg cache hit ratio (~80%) the load could be up to 5 times larger while achieving same performance
  • User actions: Each user performs 2-3 actions (clicks) per minute. The average industry rate is 1 click per 1-2 minutes.
  • Load average: starting from 0.25x users per core to 8x users per core of the application server
  • Storefront Frontend and Magento Admin actions: Performance of actions completed by customers and business users managing the storefront
  • Site Performance Tools: Performance according to sitespeed.io and Google page tests
We capture data through the experiments for the mediana, 90 percentile, 95 percentile, and 99 percentile of measured performance.
Note: the traffic profiles represent an average b2c scenario. For specific use cases like marketplace, flash sales, b2b, single product sites etc, the numbers might be significantly different.
For detailed information on our available Magento Commerce (Cloud) plans and options, see our site for plan information and DevDocs content.

blocks.title: Cloud infrastructure schema
blocks.data: Experiments run through JMeter using profiles against the Magento Cloud Pro environment. The following image details the entry point of JMeter and Production infrastructure. For additional information, see the DevDocs Magento Commerce (Cloud) guide – Pro architecture.
/resources/Content/Environment.png

blocks.title: Instances technical information
blocks.data: All tests were run in the Production environment in Magento Commerce (Cloud) Pro plan default environments.<w:br/>

To test performance of several areas of the system, the testing simulates user activity by browsing, adding to cart and buying products, among others. Graph below show the distribution of the simulated activity.

blocks.title: Reading performance results
blocks.data: Performance Experiment NameThe name of each experiment testing section details the Cloud plan, environment size, and profile of store.For example, the title “Pro12 instance with Small profile benchmarking” indicates:
Pro Cloud Plan – The Pro production environment is a dedicated server<li>12 cores Environment size<li>Small store profile size

How to interpret the graphsThe graphs show page load time (or whatever) depends on the number of traffic generating threads. When the page load time becomes unacceptable (we assume 2 seconds), you can deduct the maximum number of concurrent users the system could handle without caching.

GraphsGraphs map median measurements of performance tests for specific requests and responses. Each graph has a title for the test, legend for the tracked data, and median values. For detailed information including the 90 percentile to 99 percentile, see the corresponding tables below the graphs.

TablesThe tables provide compiled, exact values of mediana, 90 percentile, 95 percentile, and 99 percentile for each of the graphs and additional collected data from tests. Values are calculated based on full page loaded time (including HTTP request) but exclude loading any resources (images, scripts, style sheets).All values are color-coded according to benchmarks:
Green – Within benchmarks (<2 sec page load time)<li>Orange – Exceeding benchmarks (>2sec, <3 sec )<li>Red – Significantly exceeding benchmark

blocks.title: Performance tests performed
blocks.data: Three performance tests are performed for all experiments to determine performance: benchmarking, API, and client-side. All tests are available through the Magento 2 GitHub repository, the Performance Toolkit.
Benchmarking testsAll values are rated against the following benchmarks:
Server-side response, multi-thread<w:br/>
Storefront: non-cached 2 sec, cached 500 ms<li>Admin: non-cached 4 sec
API calls response: 200 ms
API performanceThese tests determine the performance of API calls and responses from the server/system

Client-side performanceAll client-side tests are single-thread. The experiment initiates actions through the storefront site as if performed by customers.To further expand on these tests, experiments include Google page speed tests and sitespeed.io. The performance tests capture reports and data from these tools profiling stores using the test profile and target Magento Cloud Infrastructure.
